7/7: We need to give the North Korean people that most dangerous of weapons—hope. The Kim regime cannot last forever. We must empower and give strength to those courageous enough to push for change.

6/7: The Kim regime is built on a series of lies about the outside world, and no lie is strong enough to last forever. Until the Kim regime one day falls, America will be on the side of the North Korean people, and not their corrupt and abusive leaders.

5/7: We seek not to impose our way of life on North Korea, but rather, to see all Koreans be able to one day express themselves in an open society of their own choosing, with leaders accountable to the population.

4/7: The President should use his platform to make clear that the American people do not desire war with North Korea. What we desire is that all the Korean people live free, prosperous, and peaceful lives. The US is not alone: many in South Korea and Japan agree!

3/7: @POTUS could turn a source of frequent criticism into a catalyst for change in North Korea that would benefit the US & our allies. His message would assuredly reach into North Korea, just as all revolutionary ideas throughout history have not been confined by borders.
2/7: I know, few people think the White House should spend more time on Twitter. And North Koreans don’t have access to Twitter in the first place.

1/7: While @POTUS is in South Korea tomorrow, he should take the opportunity to speak to the North Korean people via Twitter, much like President Reagan bypassed the Soviet regime to speak to the people of the Soviet Union. 

So, you’re probably thinking... Twitter? Hear me out.
